metadata.titleEn: A new daily gridded precipitation dataset for the Chinese mainland based on gauge observations
metadata.description: Using daily observations from 2,839 gauges across China and nearby regions from 1961 to the present, this study compared eight different interpolation schemes that adjust the climatology based on monthly precipitation constraint and topographic characteristic correction, using an algorithm that combines the daily climatology field with a precipitation ratio field. Results from these eight interpolation schemes are cross validated using 45,992 high-density daily gauge observations from 2015 to 2019 over China. Of these eight schemes, the one with the best performance merges the Parameter-elevation Regression on Independent Slopes Model (PRISM) in the daily climatology field and interpolates station observations into the ratio field using an inverse distance weighting method. This scheme has a correlation coefficient of 0.78, a root-mean-square deviation of 8.8 mm/d, and a Kling-Gupta efficiency of 0.69 for comparisons between the 45,992 high-density gauge observations and the best interpolation scheme for the 0.1° latitude × longitude grid cells from 2015 to 2019. Therefore, this scheme is used to construct a new long-term gauge-based gridded precipitation dataset across mainland China (called CHM_PR, as a member of the China Hydro-Meteorology dataset) with spatial resolutions of 0.1°/0.25°/0.5°. This precipitation dataset is expected to facilitate the advancement of drought monitoring, flood forecasting, and hydrological modeling.

background: High-quality, freely accessible, long-term precipitation estimates with fine spatiotemporal resolution play essential roles in hydrologic, climatic, and numerical modeling applications. However, the existing daily gridded precipitation datasets over China are either constructed with insufficient gauge observations or neglect topographic effects and boundary effects on interpolation.
research objective: Therefore, this study aimed to construct a long-term (from 1961 to the present) daily precipitation dataset with different spatial resolutions (0.5°×0.5°, 0.25°×0.25°, and 0.1°×0.1°) based on 2839 gauge observations in and around China (2419 gauges located across the Chinese mainland and 420 gauges from nearby regions).
challenges: However, due to the spatial heterogeneity and temporal variability in daily precipitation, it is challenging to derive accurate spatiotemporal patterns of daily precipitation. This limitation can lead to boundary effects such that grid cells near the boundaries suffer positioning inaccuracy in relation to interior grid cells (Ahrens, 2006). In addition, different interpolation algorithms can produce different results even with the same inputs.
methods: Using daily observations from 2839 gauges located across China and nearby regions from 1961 to the present, this study compared eight different interpolation schemes that adjusted the climatology based on a monthly precipitation constraint and topographic characteristic correction, using an algorithm that combined the daily climatology field with a precipitation ratio field.
dataset: Using daily observations from 2839 gauges located across China and nearby regions from 1961 to the present.
findings: Generally, the performances of CC, RMSE, and KGE in southeast China were all better than those in northwest China and the Tibetan Plateau, where the density of stations is relatively sparse. Therefore, the best scheme (PRISM +IDW) was used to construct the new 62-year CHM_PRE dataset for the Chinese mainland. Scheme 4 had better performance than the other schemes because it considers the impact of topography more deeply and holds an appropriate balance between local data fidelity and global fitting smoothness.

background: Reconstruction of natural streamﬂow is fundamental to the sustainable management of water resources. In China, previous reconstructions from sparse and poor-quality gauge measurements have led to large biases in simulation of the interannual and seasonal variability of natural ﬂows. Balancing water supply and demand for sustainable water management across different regions is highly dependent on accurate, reliable surface ﬂow records. Collection of long-term observational streamﬂow datasets worldwide is necessary to provide an evidence-based foundation for hydrological studies. China has serious water scarcity problems given that it has only one-quarter of the world average of per capita freshwater resources. The uneven distribution of water resources driven by a monsoon climate and complicated topography has exacerbated water scarcity across China. In fact, observed ﬂow regimes are greatly affected by human activities, including water diversion, water withdrawal, and reservoir operation. Thus natural streamﬂow estimation is needed for comparison with previous streamﬂow records and to help interpret climate information (e.g., precipitation and temperature) in hydrometeorology studies. Hydrological models that incorporate both the physical and climatic characteristics of basins appear effective tools to reconstruct the ﬂow of a regulated river system.
research objective: Our objective is to develop an effective high-quality scheme to reconstruct China’s natural streamﬂow, leading to long-term continuous monthly streamﬂow datasets from 1961 to 2018 for 330 catchments. These long-term national datasets are useful in the assessment and allocation of natural water resources, and in studying the impact of climate change on the terrestrial water cycle in China. Such developed streamﬂow datasets without anthropogenic inﬂuences are vitally needed in the worldwide effort to tackle the water crisis and strengthen resilience to climate change.
challenges: Traditional gauge measurements are unable to represent long-term natural hydrological variations. Reconstruction of natural ﬂows is very complex because it involves several non-linear hydrological processes and a variety of spatiotemporal scales, ranging from watershed to global and from months to millennia. Traditional reconstruction methods, such as the water balance method and regression method, encounter problems when describing the natural ﬂow in a basin with strong anthropogenic disturbances, scarce observations, and dynamic surrounding environment.
methods: Here we use a well-trained and tested land surface model coupled to a routing model with ﬂow direction correction to reconstruct the ﬁrst high-quality gauge-based natural streamﬂow dataset for China, covering all its 330 catchments during the period from 1961 to 2018. We ran the VIC model version 4.2 in water balance mode for daily time step increments. We also introduce a parameter-uncertainty analysis framework including sensitivity analysis, optimization, and regionalization, which further minimizes biases between modeled and inferred natural streamﬂow from natural or near-natural gauges. The VIC model was established on a 0.25°×0.25° grid, with meteorological forcing including daily precipitation, maximum and minimum temperatures, and wind speed variables taken from 2,400 weather stations. We manually corrected the D8 ﬂow direction based on the 330 gauge locations, corresponding gauge areas, and high-resolution river ﬂowlines. To control the quality of the reconstructed streamﬂow data, a large dataset of monthly inferred natural/near-natural streamﬂow records from 1961 to 1979 for 330 gauge stations was used to train and test the models. Both the land-surface model and routing model were trained. For the routing model test, we checked that the number of upstream routing cells (0.25°×0.25°) matched the observed drainage area for each gauge station. Parameter regionalization transferred optimized parameters from gauged to ungauged catchments. We used four global sensitivity analysis methods to screen important parameters for the 10 water resources regions of China. Then an adaptive surrogate modeling-based optimization (ASMO) was used to find the optimal parameter solution. The multiscale parameter regionalization (MPR) technique estimated values for the optimal parameter in ungauged areas. As a benchmark reference to natural records, streamﬂow data from a subset of 230 stations were used to train the coupled land-surface and routing model, thus reconstructing China’s natural streamﬂow. We tuned the sensitive parameters of modeled streamﬂow for each training station in succession from upstream to downstream during the calibration period (1961–1969) and estimated the corresponding parameters for ungauged areas.
findings: The resulting behavior of the natural hydrological system is represented properly by the model which achieves high skill metric values of the monthly streamﬂow, with about 83% of the 330 catchments having Nash-Sutcliffe efﬁciency coefﬁcient (NSE) > 0.7, and about 56% of the 330 catchments having Kling-Gupta efﬁciency coefﬁcient (KGE) > 0.7.

background: Reliable, spatiotemporally continuous runoff records are necessary for identifying climate change impacts and planning effective water management strategies. Existing Chinese runoff data to date have been produced from sparse, poor-quality gauge measurements at different time scales.
research objective: We have developed a new, quality-controlled gridded runoff dataset, the China Natural Runoff Dataset version 1.0 (CNRD v1.0), which provides daily, monthly, and annual 0.25° runoff estimates for the period 1961–2018 over China.
challenges: Although gauges can directly measure streamflow from river channels and the hillslope, such point measurements are sparse; also, the number of hydrometric stations has declined in many parts of the world. Current data collection networks are inadequate for providing the information required to understand and explain changes in natural systems. There is an extreme lack of gauged streamflow data in the Arctic and the Tibetan Plateau owing to their harsh environments. Flow measurements usually have data gaps due to technical or maintenance issues; for instance, hydrological stations can be damaged during flood events. These missing records in the datasets can cause erroneous summary data interpretation or unreliable scientific analysis. However, construction of these global datasets remains resource intensive, and they contain notable data gaps in some regions, especially in China.
methods: CNRD v1.0 was generated using the Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC) model. A comprehensive parameter uncertainty analysis framework incorporating parameter sensitivity analysis, optimization, and regionalization with 200 natural or near-natural gauge catchments was used to train the VIC model.
dataset: CNRD v1.0 is the first free public dataset of gridded natural runoff estimated using a comprehensive model parameter uncertainty analysis framework for China.
findings: Overall, the results show well-calibrated parameters for most gauged catchments except arid and semiarid areas, and the skill scores present high values for all catchments. For the pseudo-/test-ungauged catchments, the model parameters estimated by the multiscale parameter regionalization technique offer the best regionalization solution.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that addresses the challenge of spatial heterogeneity in daily precipitation data?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method that addresses the challenge of spatial heterogeneity in daily precipitation data is the use of a combination of eight different interpolation schemes that adjust climatology based on monthly precipitation constraints and topographic characteristic corrections, as applied to gauge observations across China and nearby regions.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that has been developed to improve the accuracy of natural streamflow estimations in regions with strong anthropogenic disturbances?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset developed to improve the accuracy of natural streamflow estimations is the long-term continuous monthly streamflow dataset from 1961 to 2018 for 330 catchments in China, which was reconstructed using a land surface model coupled to a routing model with flow direction correction, incorporating gauge-based data and a parameter uncertainty analysis framework.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how parameter uncertainty analysis is used in creating a reliable runoff dataset?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'topographic characteristic correction' in the context of constructing precipitation datasets?
Definition.Answer: Topographic characteristic correction involves adjusting precipitation data to account for the effects of terrain on precipitation patterns. This correction helps improve the accuracy of spatial and temporal precipitation estimates by considering how topography influences precipitation distribution.

Definition.Question: What does 'parameter regionalization' mean when developing hydrological models?
Definition.Answer: Parameter regionalization refers to the process of transferring optimized model parameters from gauged catchments to ungauged areas. This technique helps estimate parameter values for regions lacking direct observations, thereby improving model accuracy in simulating natural streamflow across diverse catchments.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of data collection in precipitation datasets differ from those in runoff datasets, particularly regarding the effects of sparse gauge measurements and topographic influences?
Comparison.Answer: Precipitation datasets face challenges with spatial heterogeneity and topographic effects that influence interpolation accuracy. Runoff datasets, on the other hand, struggle with sparse gauge measurements and missing data due to technical issues, which impact the continuity and reliability of the data.

Interpretation.Question: How do the limitations of traditional gauge measurements impact the reconstruction of natural streamflow data?
Interpretation.Answer: Traditional gauge measurements are insufficient to represent long-term natural hydrological variations due to non-linear hydrological processes, spatiotemporal scale diversity, and anthropogenic disturbances. These challenges necessitate the use of sophisticated modeling techniques to accurately reconstruct natural streamflow data, overcoming the limitations of scarce observations and dynamic environmental conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn from the use of parameter-uncertainty analysis frameworks in constructing gridded runoff datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of parameter-uncertainty analysis frameworks facilitates the calibration and optimization of model parameters, ensuring high-quality and reliable gridded runoff datasets. This approach helps address data gaps and improves regionalization solutions, especially in ungauged or sparsely gauged catchments, by effectively managing parameter sensitivity and enhancing model predictions across diverse hydrological conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the spatial heterogeneity and temporal variability in daily precipitation data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The spatial heterogeneity and temporal variability in daily precipitation data collection are caused by the complex nature of precipitation patterns, which can vary significantly across different geographical regions and times. These variations can lead to boundary effects and positioning inaccuracies in grid cells, especially near the boundaries, as well as challenges in accurately deriving spatiotemporal patterns.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to reconstruct natural streamflow from traditional gauge measurements in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Reconstructing natural streamflow from traditional gauge measurements is challenging due to several factors, including the complexity of non-linear hydrological processes, the variety of spatiotemporal scales involved, and the influence of strong anthropogenic disturbances. Scarcity of observations and dynamic environmental conditions further complicate the reconstruction process.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the inadequacy of existing data collection networks in providing reliable runoff records?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The inadequacy of existing data collection networks in providing reliable runoff records is primarily due to sparse and declining numbers of hydrometric stations, particularly in harsh environments like the Arctic and Tibetan Plateau. Additionally, technical or maintenance issues can cause data gaps, leading to unreliable analysis and interpretation of natural systems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on the spatial resolution of precipitation datasets if topographic characteristic correction is applied during data collection?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying topographic characteristic correction during data collection can lead to improved accuracy in representing spatial variability of precipitation, as it considers the impact of terrain on precipitation distribution. This approach is likely to enhance the resolution of precipitation datasets by reducing boundary effects and improving positioning accuracy of grid cells, particularly in regions with complex topography.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of creating a gridded runoff dataset for China using a comprehensive parameter uncertainty analysis framework?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals of creating a gridded runoff dataset are to provide reliable, spatiotemporally continuous runoff records that can be used to identify climate change impacts and plan effective water management strategies. This involves addressing the limitations of sparse and poor-quality gauge measurements by using an uncertainty analysis framework to calibrate model parameters and ensure robust runoff estimates across various catchments in China.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can a long-term daily precipitation dataset be constructed with varying spatial resolutions while ensuring accuracy in areas with sparse station density?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A long-term daily precipitation dataset can be constructed using daily observations from a network of gauges, adjusting climatology based on a monthly precipitation constraint, and incorporating topographic characteristic corrections. Various interpolation schemes can be compared, and the best-performing scheme, such as PRISM combined with IDW, can be used to account for topography and achieve a balance between local fidelity and global smoothness.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in reconstructing natural streamflow data for regions impacted by strong anthropogenic influences?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Reconstructing natural streamflow data involves using a land surface model coupled with a routing model with flow direction correction. The process includes running a model like VIC in water balance mode, correcting flow directions, performing parameter uncertainty analysis, and regionalizing parameters to minimize bias. Calibration involves training and testing the model with datasets from natural or near-natural gauges, adjusting parameters upstream to downstream during a calibration period, and estimating parameters for ungauged areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches can be used to address data gaps and sparse measurements in the creation of a gridded runoff dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address data gaps and sparse measurements, a gridded runoff dataset can be created using a model like the Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC) model, incorporating a parameter uncertainty analysis framework. This involves sensitivity analysis, optimization, and regionalization with available catchment data to train the model, ensuring well-calibrated parameters for gauged catchments and using regionalization techniques for ungauged areas. This comprehensive approach helps achieve reliable runoff estimates despite sparse measurements.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the creation of high-resolution precipitation datasets over large geographic areas like China, and how do they address topographic and boundary effects?
Enablement.Answer: Data collection methods that enable the creation of high-resolution precipitation datasets over large geographic areas involve using a combination of gauge observations and interpolation techniques that account for topographic and boundary effects. This approach includes adjusting the climatology based on monthly precipitation constraints and applying topographic characteristic corrections, as well as employing various interpolation schemes to minimize boundary effects and accurately represent spatial variations in precipitation.

Enablement.Question: What modeling techniques enable the generation of gridded runoff datasets in regions with sparse gauge data, and how do they ensure the reliability of these datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Modeling techniques that enable the generation of gridded runoff datasets in regions with sparse gauge data include using the Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC) model along with a comprehensive parameter uncertainty analysis framework. This approach ensures reliability by incorporating parameter sensitivity analysis, optimization, and regionalization to calibrate model parameters accurately, even in ungauged catchments, thus providing quality-controlled and continuous runoff estimates.

Expectation.Question: Why might a data collection method for daily precipitation estimates face challenges in accurately representing spatiotemporal patterns?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges may arise due to the spatial heterogeneity and temporal variability in daily precipitation, leading to boundary effects where grid cells near the boundaries suffer positioning inaccuracies compared to interior grid cells. Additionally, different interpolation algorithms can yield varied results even with the same inputs.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that a new dataset for China's natural streamflow would need to incorporate both physical and climatic characteristics of basins?
Expectation.Answer: It is expected because traditional gauge measurements are insufficient to represent long-term natural hydrological variations, especially in basins with strong anthropogenic disturbances or scarce observations. A dataset incorporating physical and climatic characteristics can more effectively model natural flow by considering complex non-linear hydrological processes.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset for natural runoff in China present challenges in data collection, particularly in specific regions like the Arctic and the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in data collection in these regions may stem from their harsh environments, leading to sparse point measurements and a decline in the number of hydrometric stations. Additionally, technical or maintenance issues can create data gaps, complicating the understanding and explanation of changes in natural systems.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential benefits and limitations of employing a comprehensive parameter uncertainty analysis framework in developing gridded runoff datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Employing a comprehensive parameter uncertainty analysis framework can significantly enhance the reliability of gridded runoff datasets by optimizing model parameters and improving calibration across catchments. This approach addresses uncertainties and enhances the ability to estimate runoff in ungauged areas. However, limitations may arise in arid and semiarid regions where even advanced models struggle with parameter estimation due to extreme environmental conditions and sparse data.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how interpolation algorithms can affect the accuracy of spatial precipitation data.
Assertion.Answer: Different interpolation algorithms can produce varying results even with the same input data due to spatial heterogeneity and temporal variability in daily precipitation. This can lead to boundary effects, where grid cells near the boundaries experience inaccuracies in positioning compared to interior grid cells.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how anthropogenic influences are accounted for in streamflow data reconstruction.
Assertion.Answer: Reconstruction of natural streamflow involves using a land surface model coupled with a routing model, which includes flow direction correction and parameter-uncertainty analysis to minimize biases. This approach helps differentiate natural streamflow from those altered by human activities such as water diversion and reservoir operations.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data gaps in runoff records are addressed in hydrological datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Data gaps in runoff records are addressed by employing models like the Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC) model, which includes a parameter uncertainty analysis framework that helps optimize and regionalize parameters, ensuring consistent data representation even in regions with sparse gauging stations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore various data collection methods that can address the challenges of spatial heterogeneity and temporal variability in daily precipitation data.
Request/Directive.Answer: Using daily observations from 2839 gauges located across China and nearby regions, eight different interpolation schemes were compared. These schemes adjusted the climatology based on a monthly precipitation constraint and topographic characteristic correction, combining the daily climatology field with a precipitation ratio field to address spatial heterogeneity and temporal variability challenges.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline potential strategies for developing a high-quality, long-term streamflow dataset that accurately reflects natural hydrological variations in regions with sparse observations and strong anthropogenic disturbances.
Request/Directive.Answer: An effective strategy involves using a well-trained and tested land surface model coupled with a routing model, including flow direction correction. A parameter-uncertainty analysis framework is introduced, which includes sensitivity analysis, optimization, and regionalization. This minimizes biases between modeled and inferred natural streamflow, utilizing meteorological forcing from multiple weather stations and incorporating manual corrections for flow directions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an overview of methods for constructing a comprehensive runoff dataset in regions with limited gauge data availability, particularly focusing on parameter uncertainty analysis.
Request/Directive.Answer: To construct a comprehensive runoff dataset, the Variable Infiltration Capacity (VIC) model is used. A parameter uncertainty analysis framework is incorporated, which involves sensitivity analysis, optimization, and regionalization with natural or near-natural gauge catchments to train the model. This approach ensures well-calibrated parameters and offers solutions for pseudo-/test-ungauged catchments using multiscale parameter regionalization techniques.
